data.title: LIST: Grand Strand, Pee Dee cities, counties provide updates during Tropical Storm Debby
data.meta_description: Grand Strand cities, utility companies, and state authorities are preparing for impacts from Debby.
data.text:
MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. (WMBF) - Grand Strand cities, utility companies, and state authorities are preparing for impacts from Debby.

According to the WMBF First Alert Weather Team the worst impacts will be through the middle of the week with heavy rain, flash flooding and tropical storm-force winds being the primary threats.

THE LATEST

LOOK: Tropical Storm Debby causes flooding in the Pee Dee, inland Horry County

LIST: School closings, other events rescheduled due to Tropical Storm Debby

President Biden approves McMaster’s emergency declaration ahead of Tropical Storm Debby

Here is how local and state agencies are taking precautions.

HORRY COUNTY

Horry County moved to Operation Condition (OPCON) 1 Wednesday morning, meaning the county is “operating at full alert to address any impacts from the storm.”

With this move, the county’s Emergency Operations Center is now activated.

Government offices and facilities will operate normally on Wednesday, but you are encouraged to call departments first or utilize the county’s online services.

All government buildings and facilities will be closed on Thursday and Horry County Solid Waste Authority facilities--including the landfill and all recycling convenience centers--will be closed, and Parks & Recreation and Library programs will be canceled.

Normal operations will resume on Friday.

In a news release, the county also issued these storm safety reminders:

Bringing in or securing yard items and decorations.

Maintaining awareness of weather conditions.

Avoiding flooded roadways.

Continually monitoring reputable weather information sources such as local media or the National Hurricane Center for the most up-to-date hurricane information.

GEORGETOWN COUNTY

The Georgetown County Council approved an emergency declaration ahead of Tropical Storm Debby. The declaration will go into effect at 8 a.m. on Tuesday and will allow emergency management officials and first responders access to “utilize all resources reasonably necessary to cope with a disaster.”

It will remain in effect for 61 days unless terminated sooner.

The county downgraded to OPCON 2 Wednesday evening, asking residents to stay vigilant as Debby passes through.

The Georgetown County Emergency Operations Center will also wrap up 24-hour operations at 7 p.m. Wednesday and will reopen at 8 a.m. Thursday. The disaster call center will also stop at 7 p.m. Wednesday and will not reopen.

The county also has a webpage on Debby.

FLORENCE COUNTY

The Florence County Sheriff’s Office and other officials said a county-wide curfew has been extended through Friday at sunrise due to the excessive rainfall and flooding in low-lying areas and roads. Roads have been closed due to flooding, that list can be found here.

Exceptions to the curfew still include essential public safety/medical employees and essential business and industry staff until further notice.

“This curfew is intended to discourage only unnecessary travel at night when road conditions are more hazardous because of ponding water and low visibility,” FCSO spokesperson Maj. Michael Nunn said. “It is NOT designed to prevent or discourage business travel, routine driving to or from work, or for other necessary purposes.”

DARLINGTON COUNTY

Darlington County officials said its local government to include recycling and trash convenience locations will be closed Wednesday and Thursday.

The county’s emergency operations center will remain open. Damage and other impacts can be reported by calling 843-398-4469. County residents can also receive text alerts and notifications by texting “Darlington” to 99411.

MYRTLE BEACH

The Myrtle Beach Emergency Management Division moved OPCON 3 on Thursday after the storm passed, meaning it is back at a normal state of operations.

Officials also said double red flags remain on the beaches, meaning no swimming is allowed.

Residents are also asked to save these important reporting contacts:

Non-emergency Police and Fire: 843-918-1382

Public Works: 843-918-2000

Parks Damages: 843-918-1188

Downed power lines: 888-769-7688 (Santee Cooper)

Report electrical outages directly to your provider.

And as always, for life-threatening emergencies dial 911.

NORTH MYRTLE BEACH

The North Myrtle Beach officials continue to monitor Tropical Storm Debby and the Emergency Operations Center will remain open until 7 p.m. Thursday. After that, they will move from OPCON 1 to OPCON 3, which will resume normal daily operations.

Out of an abundance of caution, fire, police and public works crews are available to monitor conditions overnight Thursday.

CONWAY

The City of Conway moved to an OPCON 2 level on Monday afternoon. It means the city is operating at a heightened state of awareness because of Debby. The Emergency Operations Center is not currently activated and crews are continuing to make preparations.

Conway announced that city offices and facilities will be closed on Thursday.

Solid waste collection for Thursday has also been canceled. Residents are being asked to not put yard debris by the curb in order to avoid blocking stormwater drains.

Conway Municipal Court on Thursday has been canceled and will be rescheduled. The city will mail the rescheduled court date to those impacted. Anyone with questions can call 843-248-1765.

The Waccamaw Coast Line Railroad Bridge is closed for Marine traffic because of anticipated water levels. A date for returning to normal operations for the bridge will be determined later.

SURFSIDE BEACH

Surfside Beach Mayor Robert Krouse signed a state of emergency declaration Monday ahead of Debby’s arrival in the Carolinas.

The town will move to OPCON 1 at noon on Wednesday and the emergency center is fully open and all emergency personnel are ready to be deployed if necessary.

The town also said crews are working to lower lake levels, pre-position road barricades, remove banners, stockpile sand, turn off fountains and bubblers as well as pre-checking debris removal equipment like chainsaws and other tools.

The town offices will also close early on Tuesday at 4 p.m. for the safety of the employees and will remain closed through Thursday, Aug. 8. Normal office hours will resume on Friday. All essential personnel including the town administrator and communication coordinator are working.

The pier will close at 5 p.m. on Tuesday and a double red flag has been declared for Surfside Beach.

GEORGETOWN

The city of Georgetown is providing sand and bags starting at 10 a.m. Monday morning. Residents can fill bags at the old City Hall at 120 N Frasier St. Shovels will be provided but you’re encouraged to bring your own.

FLORENCE

City offices will remain open as weather conditions permit. Police, fire, public works and utilities will be respond to situations as weather conditions permit.

The city of Florence issued the following closures and cancellations:

The Sanitation Division plans to run garbage collection this week as scheduled as long as weather conditions allow. Recycling WILL NOT be collected beginning Wednesday, Aug. 7 through Friday, Aug. 9. Should weather conditions deteriorate, collection may be postponed to ensure the safety of our workers.

The Alligator Road Flushing Initiative originally scheduled to begin Monday, Aug. 5 is postponed. The city will notify the public of a new start date for the initiative once it has been rescheduled.

The Jayne H. Boswell Animal Shelter will be closed to the public beginning Wednesday, Aug. 7 through Friday, Aug. 9.

For non-emergency events such as water or sewer disruptions, down trees, flooded or blocked streets and other public safety concerns, residents should call 843-665-3236 or 843-665-3191. As always for emergencies call 911.

DARLINGTON

The city announced it will be closing the administrative offices on Wednesday and could possibly reopen on Thursday. A decision to re-open will be made late Wednesday night. All emergency personnel will still report for duty.

MARION

The city will open a shelter for anyone impacted by the storm Wednesday morning. The shelter will be at the Shannon Wilkerson Gym on W. Bobby Gerald Parkway.

MULLINS

Mullins Police Department announced a mandatory curfew for the city which will take effect Wednesday, Aug. 7 from 8 p.m. through Thursday at 6 a.m. The hours may vary depending on the severity of the storm.

Mullins Municipal Court will also be closed and all court dates will be canceled on Wednesday. Anyone with a court date will receive a letter with new date information.

ROBESON COUNTY

Due to flooding, the RCSO administrative buildings extended closures through Friday. Normal operations will resume on Monday. Anyone needing assistance from a deputy is asked to call 910-671-3170 or if it’s an emergency 911.

SCOTLAND COUNTY

The Scotland County Board of Commissioners Chair Tim Ivey issued a state of emergency for the county effective Tuesday at 6 p.m.

LUMBERTON

Mayor Pro Tem Owen Thomas tells WMBF News the city is building a temporary berm along I-95.

Thomas said the storm isn’t expected to affect the city like Matthew did in 2016.

However, river cresting could still be detrimental with Debby, especially with construction along I-95, Thomas said.

MAXTON

The Maxton Police Department says the town’s curfew will be lifted at 7 a.m. Friday after being in effect since Wednesday.

SCDES

The South Carolina Department of EnvironmentalServices is working with the state’s lead agency during a hurricane or tropical storm response, the South Carolina Emergency Management Division, and preparing for potential impacts.

SCDES used its emergency notification system to tell owners of dams and reservoirs across the state to start taking proactive steps to prepare for potential heavy rainfall.

In addition, the agency said staff are performing pre-storm assessments at high-hazard dams expected to be heavily impacted by rainfall.

If needed after the storm, the agency will perform “post-storm dam inspections, deploy mobile teams to severely impacted areas of the state, conduct post-storm aerial coastal assessments, issue authorizations for sand scraping or minor renourishment along beaches, and assist with solid- and hazardous-waste disposal and debris disposal at landfills, among other key actions.”

SCDOT

The South Carolina Department of Transportation is keeping an eye on flash flooding or ponding on roadways as early as Monday.SCDOT urges drivers never to drive through standing water. The agency said its crews have spent the weekend clearing storm drains and preparing supplies and staging equipment.

SANTEE COOPER

Santee Cooper is drawing down the Santee Cooper Lakes in anticipation for rainfall over the next several days. The utility is also checking and fueling vehicles including line trucks, making sure communications equipment is in working order, and relocating equipment and personnel.

HTC

HTC is working to get ready for the storm by testing and fueling standby generators, inspecting network offices and equipment locations to prevent flooding, preparing fleet vehicles for deployment and other tasks to help ensure the safety of network equipment

“HTC crews and employees are preparing for the storm and are committed to keeping members connected when it matters most,” HTC CEO Carlton Lewis said. “We urge everyone to have a family emergency plan in place in preparation for the possible impacts related to Hurricane Debby.”

RED CROSS

The Red Cross is preparing to respond and wants you to follow these tips to get prepared. Know the difference between a watch and a warning, stay informed, check your emergency kit, prepare to evacuate quickly, don’t forget your pets, stay indoors; avoid beaches, riverbanks, and, floodwaters, remember to turn around, don’t drown, use flashlights in the dark if the power goes out.

SALVATION ARMY

Both the Salvation Army’s Georgetown and Conway Emergency Disaster Vehicles, along with its Regional Mobile Kitchen Trailer, are being prepared in anticipation of providing meals and support.

GRAND STRAND HEALTH

The medical center announced the closure of a number of physician practices and outpatient facilities for the safety of patients and staff. Those closures are listed below. These locations will be closed Wednesday, Aug. 7, and will reopen on Friday, Aug. 9:

CareNow Urgent Care Facilities

Cardiac Rehab Services at Grand Strand Medical Center

Carolina Forest Imaging Center

Grand Strand Health Physician Practices

Grand Strand Bariatric Surgery

Grand Strand Cosmetic & Reconstructive Care

Grand Strand Facial & Jaw Surgery

Grand Strand Heart & Vascular Care

Grand Strand Infectious Disease

Grand Strand Orthopedic Care

Grand Strand Primary Care

Grand Strand Spine & Neuro Care

Grand Strand Surgical Care

Outpatient Lab Services at Grand Strand Health’s Medical Office Building

South Strand Medical Center’s Outpatient Imaging and Lab Services

The Advanced Wound Center

The Breast Center – closing at 1 p.m. on August 7

Not including the practices listed above the Grand Strand Medical Center, South Strand Medical Center, North Strand ER and Carolina Forest ER will remain open for the storm.

TIDELANDS HEALTH

Tidelands Health hospitals and emergency departments are operating normally.

Stay with WMBF News for updates.
